title: Which is correct, 'we got to the hall after the play WAS started' or 'we got to the hall after the play HAD started' or 'we got to the hall after the play HAVE started'? - Quora

response.answer_text: From the 3 phrases mentioned, ONLY “We got to the hall after the play HAD started” IS CORRECT (see clarification below). “We got to the hall after the play was started” [focusing on the action by ??] suggests one came too late to actively join one’s team. However, “was started” suggests one witnessed the start [the action] whereas one wasn’t even there yet, which MAKES NO SENSE.For that reason, I would call it WRONG.I would INSTEAD say “We got to the hall after the play had been started”, as this clearly expresses one wasn’t there yet when the play was (YES: was!) started [“had been” expressing an action by ??? that one did not witness when it took place].This is CORRECT English AND MAKES SENSE.This phrase has not been given by you, though.“We got to the hall after the play had started” suggests one came to passively watch the play, but missed its beginning and possibly the entire play (dependant on whether one could still enter the hall). “The play had started” indicates a situation (the play was being played when one got to the hall), rather than an action (transition).This phrase is CORRECT AND MAKES SENSE.“We got to the hall after the play have started” is grammatically WRONG as the direct verb “have” does not correspond with the third person singular subject “the play”. Moreover, the present tense in “have” does not correspond with the past tense in “got”.Hence, my conclusion in the first line above. Kind Regards, André

response.answer_text: The two former snippets are perfectly acceptable in the way of English grammar. The first may sound a bit wierder than the second because “the play was started” is in passive voice—it’s acceptable, but I would recommend active voice—”we got to the hall after the play had started” would be the best way to say it. The third snippet, however, does not meet the standards of English grammar. The problem is that “have” is being used in the past tense when it is usually used in the present tense. “Have” is both the present tense form and the infinitive form of the verb. It is likely that you were uncertain about which form of the word to use so that it matched the tense that the sentence was in.
